markdown.headingText: {{< fa satellite title="satellite" >}} my research path
markdown.markdown:
I’m currently a Ph.D. student in the [Geography department]( https://www.geog.ucsb.edu/){target="_blank"} at UC Santa Barbara.

I earned both my bachelor's and master's degrees in Geography from National Taiwan University (NTU). During my undergraduate years, I discovered a deep passion for being outdoors—hiking the trails around Taipei and observing the natural environment.

:::{.column-margin}
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-alt: "A typical day in MCF of Chilan, Taiwan"
knitr::include_graphics("media/CL.jpg")
```
::: {.center-text .extra-small-text .dark-gray-text .topbr}
A typical day in Chilan, Taiwan. The photo shot from the top of a flux tower at 14.5K.
:::
:::


One class that particularly inspired me was **Discovery of Montane Cloud Forests in Taiwan**, which I took in my junior year. I was drawn to the idea that we could do science by combining indoor analysis with outdoor exploration. For my senior project, I conducted a study titled **Analyzing the Factors of Windthrow by Typhoons in Chilan Mountain**, using Landsat imagery and field measurements to investigate what environmental factors (e.g. slope, aspect, elevation etc.) contribute to higher windthrow risks in the montane forests of northern Taiwan.

:::{.column-margin}
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-alt: "a human with a tree"
knitr::include_graphics("media/me_with_tree.jpg")
```
::: {.center-text .extra-small-text .dark-gray-text}
I was measuring a really gigantic hinoki.
:::
:::

That early research experience led me to pursue a master’s degree under the guidance of my advisor, [Choy Huang]( https://sites.google.com/site/choyhuang/){target="_blank"}. My thesis, **Assessment of Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Fog Daily Duration in Montane Cloud Forests of Northeast Taiwan**, aimed to quantify fog frequency in montane cloud forests (MCFs) using Himawari-8 satellite imagery and meteorological field data. I used a random forest model to predict fog occurrence across both spatial and temporal scales.
For a long time, our understanding of high-frequency fog in montane cloud forests (MCFs) was based mostly on rough estimates. [My work](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0168192322000922?via%3Dihub){target="_blank"} was the first to quantify fog frequency in this ecosystem, laying the foundation for future studies on how these forests may be impacted by a warming climate.

Now, as a Ph.D. student, my dissertation focuses on the impacts of drought on oak woodlands in Southern California. From working in environments with over 100% relative humidity to ecosystems where RH drops below 30%, I’ve found that what I enjoy most is the combination of remote sensing analysis and occasional fieldwork. My current research heavily involves **imaging spectroscopy** (a.k.a hyperspectral imagery), which captures over 300 bands across the electromagnetic spectrum, providing rich information about vegetation and ecosystem processes.

:::{.column-margin}
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-alt: "a human with a tree"
knitr::include_graphics("media/me_with_oak.jpg")
```
::: {.center-text .extra-small-text .dark-gray-text}
I was observing a brunt oak tree.
:::
:::

As a first-generation college student, I feel incredibly fortunate to have been supported by mentors, friends, and advisors throughout my academic journey. Their guidance has helped me grow when I felt stuck or uncertain. I truly believe it takes a village to nurture a student into an independent scholar. Although I am still learning, I’d be more than happy to connect with anyone interested in pursuing a similar path in geography or environmental remote sensing.


## {{< fa seedling title="seedling" >}} my hobby
I believe that one of the most important skills to develop during a Ph.D. — beyond research — is maintaining a healthy **work-life balance**. A good balance not only supports well-being but also enhances productivity and creativity.

:::{.column-margin}
```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-alt: "my climbing pic"
knitr::include_graphics("media/climbing.jpg")
```
::: {.center-text .extra-small-text .dark-gray-text .topbr}
Outdoor Climbing in SB
:::
:::

In my free time, I enjoy **running, climbing (mostly top-rope), teaching myself piano, solving Rubik’s cubes of different shapes, reading (Bible, sci-fi, self-improvement, environmental and political topics), playing board games, and hiking**. 

Since Jan. 2024, I’ve been following a 3-day-a-week running plan, and in Nov. 2024, I finished the Santa Barbara Half marathon with my PB! I also started coordinating a graduate student running club in Fall 2024, helping to build a social and supportive community for fellow graduate students at UCSB.

I began climbing in Fall 2022 and mostly climb at the UCSB Rec Center. Climbing has been incredibly rewarding — not just physically, but mentally. I've learned valuable life lessons from it. Sometimes I encounter a route that feels impossible. But with some trial and error, I often find that I can complete it a few weeks later. Most of us are capable of overcoming challenges that seem insurmountable at first — we just need the right techniques, a shift in perspective, and persistence. Climbing has taught me that many of the barriers we face are not real limits, but illusions.

**I only wish there were more hours in the day to enjoy all the things I love.** {{< fa mug-hot title="mug" >}}
